AGENCY WEBSITE

2019

Recreating an award winning website

In this stage of my web development career, I wanted to build a website that would challenge me and help bring my skills to the next level. I believe taking this project on has done just that. Because I am not a designer, I didn't think trying to design a website from scratch would be worth my effort, so I decided to pick a website that Awwwards.com, an organization that sets the standard for industry leading design and development, gave the award of Site Of The Day to. The original website is woflandwhale.com.

I tried to stay as close as I could to the original design but build it in my own way without referencing their code base. I also wanted to give the site my own twist with the name and improving small areas that I think give the site a bit more of a premium feel.

The Tech Behind
The Website

I wanted to take things back to the basics to get a better understand of building a website from the ground up without popular javascript libraries. My previous two projects were both built with React and thought an in depth refresher of using the foundational tools of web development would do me good.

With this project I also realized one doesn't necessarily need a JavaScript framework to produce a professional grade website. I chose to build this Digital Agency Website with pure html, SASS, lots of JavaScript and leveraged two of my favorite JavaScript libraries to create some nice animations to enhance the user experience and give the site a higher quality feel and look. In addition, a bundler is essential for performance, cross browser support and modular work flow support. I chose to use parcel as it is incredibly easy and reliable for development and production use.

HTML CSS SASS Parcel GSAP ScrollMagic NPM Parcel Github

A Mobile friendly approach

In todays digital age, users expect every website to have a mobile version. So companies and developers must try to produce the same of not better experience for users interacting with their site on a mobile device. This project helped me understand how a professional team translates a desktop site into a mobile device.
